descriptions.description: More maintainer time increases the rate at which issues can be resolved.
More open issues generate more feedback from users and contributors.
Increased feedback can lead to the identification and creation of more open issues.
A high number of open issues encourages contributors to submit new pull requests to address them.
The flow of new pull requests increases the stock of new pull requests awaiting initial processing.
New pull requests move into the review queue, increasing the stock under review.
A higher review rate decreases the stock of new pull requests as they are processed.
Reviewed and merged pull requests add new code to the source code stock.
Merging pull requests decreases the stock of pull requests under review.
Rejecting pull requests decreases the stock of pull requests under review.
Merged pull requests often close related issues, increasing the stock of closed issues.
Positive PR feedback encourages new contributors to remain and stay active.
Constructive PR feedback helps experienced contributors refine their skills and engagement.
Effective PR feedback identifies and nurtures potential core developers.
Timely PR feedback keeps the review process moving, affecting the review queue.
New contributors generate PR feedback through their questions and submission attempts.
Experienced contributors provide more sophisticated and detailed PR feedback.
As new contributors gain experience, they transition to become experienced contributors.
The skill-up flow decreases the stock of new contributors as they gain experience.
The skill-up flow increases the stock of experienced contributors as newcomers advance.
The promotion rate decreases the stock of experienced contributors as they are promoted.
The promotion rate increases the stock of core developers by advancing experienced contributors.
More core developers reduce PR review delay by increasing review capacity.
Shorter PR review delays enable faster and more responsive PR feedback.
Developer turnover decreases the stock of core developers when they leave the project.
Developer turnover increases the depreciation of knowledge as experts depart.
A larger stock of implicit knowledge enhances the potential for effective mentorship.
Effective implicit knowledge transfer accelerates the skill-up rate for newcomers.
Strong mentorship increases the promotion rate by preparing contributors for advanced roles.
More core developers increase the capacity for implicit knowledge transfer through mentorship.
Project implicit knowledge guides the creation and refinement of explicit knowledge artifacts.
Converting explicit to implicit knowledge decreases the stock of explicit knowledge.
Converting explicit to implicit knowledge increases the stock of implicit, internalized knowledge.
More explicit knowledge improves documentation and guides for knowledge transfer.
Better explicit knowledge transfer lowers barriers, increasing the potential joining rate.
Accessible explicit knowledge accelerates the skill-up rate for all contributors.
A higher issue creation rate increases the stock of open issues.
A higher issue resolution rate increases the stock of closed issues.
A larger codebase can lead to more issues being created by users and developers.
PR feedback discussions become archived content for the searchable knowledge base.
Closed issues, especially their resolutions, add valuable content to the knowledge base.
A growing knowledge base directly contributes to the project's stock of explicit knowledge.
Community discussions are captured and added to the searchable knowledge base.
Active community engagement generates content that enriches the knowledge base.
A better project reputation attracts more potential contributors, increasing the joining rate.
A strong project reputation helps to grow and retain the user base.
A higher adoption rate increases the stock of users in the user base.
User churn decreases the user base as people stop using the software.
Reputation building activities, like releases and community wins, increase project reputation.
Reputation decline, from bugs or conflict, decreases the project's reputation stock.
High software quality and rich features enhance the project's reputation.
A large, active user base contributes to the project's visibility and reputation.
Trust-building interactions and fair processes increase the stock of community health.
Culture erosion, through conflict or toxicity, decreases the stock of community health.
A healthy community fosters a positive environment that boosts project reputation.
A positive project reputation makes the project more attractive, influencing the joining rate.
